You are likely referring to the French monarch Louis XIV, who ruled France from 1643 to 1715. Louis XIV was known for his extravagant spending, which contributed to France's financial difficulties.

In the late 17th and early 18th centuries, France experienced a period of inflation as the government printed more money to finance its spending, including wars and the construction of grand palaces such as the Palace of Versailles. This led to an increase in the money supply, which in turn led to rising prices and a decrease in the value of money.

This is an example of a phenomenon known as "monetary inflation," in which a government increases the money supply and thereby reduces the value of its currency. This can have a number of negative effects, including higher prices, decreased purchasing power, and economic instability.

There have been many other instances of monetary inflation throughout history, often as a result of wars or other government spending. In some cases, governments have devalued their currencies by printing more money or by reducing the amount of precious metals in coins, leading to hyperinflation and economic turmoil.
